<tr>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: separate" width="100%">
<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning. </strong>Tomorrow night I’ll join the rest of the Jewish community in celebrating Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish New Year. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">One of the most fascinating Rosh Hashanah customs is called <em>Tashlich</em>. During this ceremony, Jews head to a body of water—could be an ocean, river, or these days, I-676 in Philly—and throw in small pieces of bread.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It’s not a ritualized rejection of carbs, but instead an opportunity to, quite literally, “cast off” your sins to be taken away by the current, or eaten by fish. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Tashlich</em> isn’t a “get out of jail free” card to use when we mess up. Rather, it’s an understanding that we all do things we’re not proud of. Everyone makes mistakes, everyone’s accumulated a little bread over the past year. But instead of dwelling forever on what we’ve done wrong, <em>Tashlich </em>allows us to acknowledge that we're simply human...and only when you forgive yourself for your past missteps can you focus on improving in the future. And I really like that message.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Wishing everyone, whether you’re celebrating Rosh Hashanah or not, a <em>shana tovah u'metukah</em>, a good and sweet year.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">—Neal Freyman</p>
</div>

Q&A
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">

<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Icebreakers with...Habits Expert James Clear
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/03/icebreakers-withmaster-sommelier-ian-cauble?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="James Clear " style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MjkxL2phbWVzX2NsZWFyLmpwZWciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>James Clear</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">James Clear dishes out life-changing insights like they're T-shirts on a college campus. He is the author of the bestselling book, <a href="https://jamesclear.com/atomic-habits?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Atomic Habits</em></a>, as well as the hugely popular <a href="https://jamesclear.com/3-2-1?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">3-2-1 newsletter</a>. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">We tried not to bite our nails as we asked James all about building (and breaking) habits.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What is one of your ideas that most resonates with your audience?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">There are probably two. The first is the idea of systems over goals, or rather than worrying about the outcome, focusing on the process and building better habits each day. The line that people bring up a lot from the book is, “You don’t rise to the level of your goals, you fall to the level of your systems.” </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The other one that has gone over well is what I call “identity-based habits.” Rather than worrying about the results you want, focus on becoming the <em>type of person</em> who could achieve those results. So instead of worrying about losing 40 pounds, focus on being the kind of person who doesn’t miss workouts. Or rather than worrying about finishing the novel, focus on being the kind of person who writes every day.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Many people have been working from home for 18 months. Do you think that's made it more difficult to develop habits? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">One of the things that makes it hard to stick to a habit is if you’re trying to do multiple habits in the same context. Say your couch is the place where you watch Netflix at 7pm, but you want to get in the habit of journaling each night. If you try to journal at 7pm on the couch you have this unconscious bias toward turning on the TV, because that’s what usually happens there. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">One of the benefits of going into an office is that you have a defined space for work habits to live. You can utilize that idea in a practical way, by trying to create defined spaces for certain habits. If you want to get into the habit of reading, you could have a reading chair in the corner of the room. And the only thing that happens there is when you sit there you read a book. And you gradually start to associate that behavior with that context. The more explicit you can be about where the habit occurs, and it always occurs in the same place in the same way, the more likely it is that the behavior will stick.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What did you learn about habit formation from being a college baseball pitcher? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I learned a lot about the importance of pregame routines. Before every start in college I went through the same sequence about 40 minutes before the start of the game.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">What ends up happening is that a switch flips in your mind and says, “Remember, it’s time to play now.” I think that helps not just with the physical part of the task—it helps with the mental part of the task. It helps get you in the right mindset to perform.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Translating that to what I do now, since <em>Atomic Habits</em> has blown up I’ve been asked to do a lot of keynote speeches. And I have a pregame routine before I walk out on stage.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What do you do? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It usually starts with me getting a glass of water. I take a drink of water, go through the first minute of the talk in my head, and then I put my head down and have quiet time for 10 seconds or so. Then I get up, take a deep breath, and I’m ready to go.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Each of your newsletters contains two quotes. Do you have a favorite quote? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I’m going to pick two but I do just want to say I have like 100. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">One is from my friend Morgan Housel: “Your personal experiences make up maybe 0.00000001% of what’s happened in the world but maybe 80% of how you think the world works. We’re all biased to our own personal history.”</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The second one is from the investor Josh Wolfe, who said that the most useful advice he ever got was from James Watson, the scientist who helped discover DNA. Watson said three words with two meanings: “Avoid boring people.” I like that a lot because it means a) don’t hang out with boring people and b) don’t be boring yourself. Be interesting, be fascinating, do compelling things. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>This interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity. </em></p>

WORK LIFE

<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
The Keys to Getting Honest Feedback
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/03/make-work-get-honest-feedback?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Make It Work logo" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em></em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Each week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers reader-submitted questions about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ask Shane here</a>.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>I'm a relatively new manager and I want to make sure I'm providing proper support to my direct reports with any challenges they may be experiencing. Do you have any advice for soliciting honest feedback? —Michael in NYC</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I thought we had a good thing going, Michael. The honest feedback comes to <strong><em>me </em></strong>and then I address it here on Sunday—what gives?</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Bad for the advice column business or not, I love this question. The number of managers who view feedback as a one-way street would make NYC’s grid blush. The last thing you want is an employee who, in a final twist of irony, provides their only honest feedback during the exit interview. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I’ve found the best strategy for collecting feedback from employees to be a diversified one. I had a manager who would ask during every 1-1 session if I had any feedback for them, a tactic I later found myself using with a few of my direct reports. I suspect that some employees might feel put “on the spot” in that scenario and would prefer to write out their thoughts beforehand. Still others will inevitably respond best to an anonymous survey or <a href="https://www.thebalancecareers.com/360-degree-feedback-information-1917537?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">360-degree approach</a>. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Whether it’s delivered via carrier pigeon or metaverse avatar, the input (and actually doing something with it) is what matters. And while there are plenty of methods to solicit feedback, there are no real shortcuts if you want to track down the “honest” kind. You’ll need to earn it by being honest yourself—both with the feedback you give your direct reports, as well as by being transparent about your own challenges. The key is to model behavior that establishes feedback as part of a broader culture of continuous professional growth and trust, rather than relying on an annual performance review.</p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">Writing on the Wall</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Last week, I invited Brew readers to join me in helping Rachel from FL find the perfect quote to grace her blank office wall. This group is certainly not lacking inspiration—had your responses not sent me running through it, my own wall would be outfitted with vinyl lettering. In the end, though, nobody showed up in numbers quite like <em>Ted Lasso</em> Nation and so I’ve taken the liberty of mocking up the “<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_KXqWCLHgHg" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">goldfish</a>” quote for production below. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">“You know what the happiest animal on Earth is? It’s a goldfish. You know why? 10-second memory.” </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Have a question about work you want to ask Shane? </em><a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Cb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Write in here</em></a><em>. </em><em>And coming soon...HR Brew. Be one of the </em><a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24747517.1107/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubW9ybmluZ2JyZXcuY29tL2hyL3N1YnNjcmliZT91dG1fbWVkaXVtPW5ld3NsZXR0ZXImdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1jcm9zc3Byb21vJnV0bV9jYW1wYWlnbj1ocl9pbl9tb3JuaW5nYnJld18wODE0MjE/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B7b0506f5?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>first subscribers</em></a><em> to our upcoming newsletter on all things human resources.</em></p>

</a><span> </span>
<a rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none" target="_blank" href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#" class=""><img style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k5/3/p/605cd9645b910.png">
</a>

</tr>


<tr class="">
<td align="left" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 10px 0px; word-break: break-word;">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;color: #353535; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 22px; table-layout: auto; width: 100%; border: none;" width="100%">
<tr>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #ffe62e 25%, #0f9046); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border: 2px solid #353535; background: white; margin: 0px; padding: 10px;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
ANALYSIS
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Paper Menus Aren't Coming Back
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/03/mean-qr-codes-stay?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Phone scanning QR code at resturant" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MjkwL3FyX2NvZGUuanBlZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Albert Hu/Unsplash</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">2021 has a faint scent of 2011: The cool kids are dressing like they’re in <em>Gossip Girl</em>, Drake and Kanye are hyping up albums, and QR codes are trying to make it big in the US. At least one of them is succeeding. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Invented in 1994 by a Japanese engineer, QR codes have been ubiquitous in Chinese payments apps for years. But recently they've become a staple of US restaurant menus and checkout registers as companies made transactions as touchless as possible during the pandemic.</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1"><span>Over the last 18 months, QR code downloads have increased 750%, according to Bitly. </span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Half of all full-service restaurants in the US have opted for QR code menus since the beginning of the pandemic, per the National Restaurant Association. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">While pandemic winners like Peloton and Zoom have faltered as vaccinations have ramped up, don’t expect QR codes to disappear. Because of the many advantages they offer businesses, QR codes will be <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/21/qr-codes-have-replaced-restaurant-menus-industry-experts-say-it-isnt-a-fad.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">distracting us</a> in restaurants for years to come, experts say. </p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">What are the implications? </h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>More tracking.</strong> While it might seem like you’re harmlessly ordering a Denny’s Grand Slam after a long day, QR codes track when, where, and how often you scan them. That info is like candy to restaurants, which can use it to more closely track consumer behavior. </p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1"><span>Privacy experts warn that rules largely don’t exist to dictate what restaurants can and can’t do with that info, like, say, sell it to a third-party delivery app that desperately wants to send you notifications about ordering takeout.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>More scams</strong>. The ease of creating a QR code is one of the reasons why it’s so accessible for businesses, but it also increases opportunities for fraud. You can’t predict where a code will take you until you open it, making it difficult to know if it’s a scam or not.</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1">
<span>The Better Business Bureau even issued a </span><span><a href="https://www.bbb.org/article/scams/24636-bbb-scam-alert-watch-out-for-fraudulent-qr-codes?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">warning</a></span><span> this summer around fraudulent QR codes.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Replacing human workers</strong>. We’ve been worried about technology stealing our jobs since Edison’s lightbulb replaced the candle boy. But the QR code makes it real.</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li><span>Without the need for servers to take orders and deliver bills, some restaurants have cut 30%–50% of labor costs by using QR code menus, according to Tom Sharon, cofounder of the startup Cheqout, which builds the tech for those menus. Economic downturns have historically been catalysts for automation, forcing struggling businesses to cut costs where they can. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Bottom line: </strong>Just like any technology, QR codes invite both promise and peril.</p>

<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Open House
</h1>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Welcome to Open House, the only newsletter section that dares to ask the question, “Why go to a wildlife preserve when you can live in the hollow remains of one?” We’ll give you a few facts about a listing, and you try to guess the price.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><img src="https://media.giphy.com/media/ocbxMbDJGro5Z1FBBM/giphy.gif?cid=790b7611ac8c63b0a962ea4540c12e7f4804b73a3304e74a&rid=giphy.gif&ct=g" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="7,458 square-foot house in Minnesota on beach-front property filled with hundreds of taxidermied animals." data-source="Zillow" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;line-height: 22px;"><small> <em>Zillow</em> </small></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Strap in for some more rich people nonsense as we head to Cold Spring, Minnesota—90 minutes northwest of Minneapolis. This 7,458 square-foot <a href="https://www.zillow.com/homedetails/27785-Hidden-Cove-Rd-Cold-Spring-MN-56320/74877154_zpid/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Cabela’s wannabe</a> is a lakefront property with a beach, where you’ll want to spend most of your time to escape the watchful eye of the many taxidermied animals. Amenities include:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1"><span>4 beds, 5 baths</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Indoor jacuzzi tub up rock stairs</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Custom, walk-in shower</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Warthog in the bedroom</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">How much to be a big-game hunter in the sheets (and the rest of the home)?</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>$1.45 million</strong></p>

style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eTomorrow night I’ll join the rest of the Jewish community in celebrating Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish New Year. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOne of the most fascinating Rosh Hashanah customs is called \u003cem\u003eTashlich\u003c/em\u003e. During this ceremony, Jews head to a body of water—could be an ocean, river, or these days, I-676 in Philly—and throw in small pieces of bread.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt’s not a ritualized rejection of carbs, but instead an opportunity to, quite literally, “cast off” your sins to be taken away by the current, or eaten by fish. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eTashlich\u003c/em\u003e isn’t a “get out of jail free” card to use when we mess up. Rather, it’s an understanding that we all do things we’re not proud of. Everyone makes mistakes, everyone’s accumulated a little bread over the past year. But instead of dwelling forever on what we’ve done wrong, \u003cem\u003eTashlich \u003c/em\u003eallows us to acknowledge that we're simply human...and only when you forgive yourself for your past missteps can you focus on improving in the future. And I really like that message.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWishing everyone, whether you’re celebrating Rosh Hashanah or not, a \u003cem\u003eshana tovah u'metukah\u003c/em\u003e, a good and sweet year.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500\"\u003e—Neal Freyman\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"James Clear \" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MjkxL2phbWVzX2NsZWFyLmpwZWciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eJames Clear\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eJames Clear dishes out life-changing insights like they're T-shirts on a college campus. He is the author of the bestselling book, \u003ca href=\"https://jamesclear.com/atomic-habits?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eAtomic Habits\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, as well as the hugely popular \u003ca href=\"https://jamesclear.com/3-2-1?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e3-2-1 newsletter\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWe tried not to bite our nails as we asked James all about building (and breaking) habits.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is one of your ideas that most resonates with your audience?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThere are probably two. The first is the idea of systems over goals, or rather than worrying about the outcome, focusing on the process and building better habits each day. The line that people bring up a lot from the book is, “You don’t rise to the level of your goals, you fall to the level of your systems.” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe other one that has gone over well is what I call “identity-based habits.” Rather than worrying about the results you want, focus on becoming the \u003cem\u003etype of person\u003c/em\u003e who could achieve those results. So instead of worrying about losing 40 pounds, focus on being the kind of person who doesn’t miss workouts. Or rather than worrying about finishing the novel, focus on being the kind of person who writes every day.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMany people have been working from home for 18 months. Do you think that's made it more difficult to develop habits? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOne of the things that makes it hard to stick to a habit is if you’re trying to do multiple habits in the same context. Say your couch is the place where you watch Netflix at 7pm, but you want to get in the habit of journaling each night. If you try to journal at 7pm on the couch you have this unconscious bias toward turning on the TV, because that’s what usually happens there. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOne of the benefits of going into an office is that you have a defined space for work habits to live. You can utilize that idea in a practical way, by trying to create defined spaces for certain habits. If you want to get into the habit of reading, you could have a reading chair in the corner of the room. And the only thing that happens there is when you sit there you read a book. And you gradually start to associate that behavior with that context. The more explicit you can be about where the habit occurs, and it always occurs in the same place in the same way, the more likely it is that the behavior will stick.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat did you learn about habit formation from being a college baseball pitcher? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI learned a lot about the importance of pregame routines. Before every start in college I went through the same sequence about 40 minutes before the start of the game.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhat ends up happening is that a switch flips in your mind and says, “Remember, it’s time to play now.” I think that helps not just with the physical part of the task—it helps with the mental part of the task. It helps get you in the right mindset to perform.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eTranslating that to what I do now, since \u003cem\u003eAtomic Habits\u003c/em\u003e has blown up I’ve been asked to do a lot of keynote speeches. And I have a pregame routine before I walk out on stage.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat do you do? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt usually starts with me getting a glass of water. I take a drink of water, go through the first minute of the talk in my head, and then I put my head down and have quiet time for 10 seconds or so. Then I get up, take a deep breath, and I’m ready to go.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEach of your newsletters contains two quotes. Do you have a favorite quote? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI’m going to pick two but I do just want to say I have like 100. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOne is from my friend Morgan Housel: “Your personal experiences make up maybe 0.00000001% of what’s happened in the world but maybe 80% of how you think the world works. We’re all biased to our own personal history.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe second one is from the investor Josh Wolfe, who said that the most useful advice he ever got was from James Watson, the scientist who helped discover DNA. Watson said three words with two meanings: “Avoid boring people.” I like that a lot because it means a) don’t hang out with boring people and b) don’t be boring yourself. Be interesting, be fascinating, do compelling things. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F09%2F03%2Ficebreakers-withmaster-sommelier-ian-cauble\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Make It Work logo\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eEach week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers reader-submitted questions about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAsk Shane here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eI'm a relatively new manager and I want to make sure I'm providing proper support to my direct reports with any challenges they may be experiencing. Do you have any advice for soliciting honest feedback? —Michael in NYC\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI thought we had a good thing going, Michael. The honest feedback comes to \u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eme \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003eand then I address it here on Sunday—what gives?\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBad for the advice column business or not, I love this question. The number of managers who view feedback as a one-way street would make NYC’s grid blush. The last thing you want is an employee who, in a final twist of irony, provides their only honest feedback during the exit interview. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI’ve found the best strategy for collecting feedback from employees to be a diversified one. I had a manager who would ask during every 1-1 session if I had any feedback for them, a tactic I later found myself using with a few of my direct reports. I suspect that some employees might feel put “on the spot” in that scenario and would prefer to write out their thoughts beforehand. Still others will inevitably respond best to an anonymous survey or \u003ca href=\"https://www.thebalancecareers.com/360-degree-feedback-information-1917537?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e360-degree approach\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhether it’s delivered via carrier pigeon or metaverse avatar, the input (and actually doing something with it) is what matters. And while there are plenty of methods to solicit feedback, there are no real shortcuts if you want to track down the “honest” kind. You’ll need to earn it by being honest yourself—both with the feedback you give your direct reports, as well as by being transparent about your own challenges. The key is to model behavior that establishes feedback as part of a broader culture of continuous professional growth and trust, rather than relying on an annual performance review.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eWriting on the Wall\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eLast week, I invited Brew readers to join me in helping Rachel from FL find the perfect quote to grace her blank office wall. This group is certainly not lacking inspiration—had your responses not sent me running through it, my own wall would be outfitted with vinyl lettering. In the end, though, nobody showed up in numbers quite like \u003cem\u003eTed Lasso\u003c/em\u003e Nation and so I’ve taken the liberty of mocking up the “\u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_KXqWCLHgHg\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003egoldfish\u003c/a\u003e” quote for production below. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e“You know what the happiest animal on Earth is? It’s a goldfish. You know why? 10-second memory.” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eHave a question about work you want to ask Shane? \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Cb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eWrite in here\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e. \u003c/em\u003e\u003cem\u003eAnd coming soon...HR Brew. border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Phone scanning QR code at resturant\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MjkwL3FyX2NvZGUuanBlZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eAlbert Hu/Unsplash\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e2021 has a faint scent of 2011: The cool kids are dressing like they’re in \u003cem\u003eGossip Girl\u003c/em\u003e, Drake and Kanye are hyping up albums, and QR codes are trying to make it big in the US. At least one of them is succeeding. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eInvented in 1994 by a Japanese engineer, QR codes have been ubiquitous in Chinese payments apps for years. But recently they've become a staple of US restaurant menus and checkout registers as companies made transactions as touchless as possible during the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOver the last 18 months, QR code downloads have increased 750%, according to Bitly. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHalf of all full-service restaurants in the US have opted for QR code menus since the beginning of the pandemic, per the National Restaurant Association. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhile pandemic winners like Peloton and Zoom have faltered as vaccinations have ramped up, don’t expect QR codes to disappear. Because of the many advantages they offer businesses, QR codes will be \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/21/qr-codes-have-replaced-restaurant-menus-industry-experts-say-it-isnt-a-fad.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edistracting us\u003c/a\u003e in restaurants for years to come, experts say. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eWhat are the implications? \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMore tracking.\u003c/strong\u003e While it might seem like you’re harmlessly ordering a Denny’s Grand Slam after a long day, QR codes track when, where, and how often you scan them. That info is like candy to restaurants, which can use it to more closely track consumer behavior. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePrivacy experts warn that rules largely don’t exist to dictate what restaurants can and can’t do with that info, like, say, sell it to a third-party delivery app that desperately wants to send you notifications about ordering takeout.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMore scams\u003c/strong\u003e. The ease of creating a QR code is one of the reasons why it’s so accessible for businesses, but it also increases opportunities for fraud. You can’t predict where a code will take you until you open it, making it difficult to know if it’s a scam or not.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe Better Business Bureau even issued a \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bbb.org/article/scams/24636-bbb-scam-alert-watch-out-for-fraudulent-qr-codes?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewarning\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e this summer around fraudulent QR codes.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eReplacing human workers\u003c/strong\u003e. We’ve been worried about technology stealing our jobs since Edison’s lightbulb replaced the candle boy. But the QR code makes it real.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWithout the need for servers to take orders and deliver bills, some restaurants have cut 30%–50% of labor costs by using QR code menus, according to Tom Sharon, cofounder of the startup Cheqout, which builds the tech for those menus. Economic downturns have historically been catalysts for automation, forcing struggling businesses to cut costs where they can. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eJust like any technology, QR codes invite both promise and peril.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F09%2F03%2Fmean-qr-codes-stay\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block;
